data:
Tumor size is a key factor in determining the T stage of breast cancer.
T1 tumors are those that measure 2 cm or less in size.
T2 tumors measure more than 2 cm but not more than 5 cm in greatest dimension.
T3 tumors measure more than 5 cm in greatest dimension.
T4 tumors involve the chest wall or the skin.
T stage is determined by the largest dimension of the tumor, unless there is multifocal or multicentric disease, in which case the T stage is determined by the total tumor size.
Tumor size is determined by gross or microscopic measurement.
Tumor size should not include any associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).

Tumor size is a key factor in determining the T stage of breast cancer.
T1 tumors are those that measure 2 cm or less in size.
T2 tumors measure more than 2 cm but not more than 5 cm in greatest dimension.
T3 tumors measure more than 5 cm in greatest dimension.
T4 tumors involve the chest wall or the skin.
T stage is determined by the largest dimension of the tumor, unless there is multifocal or multicentric disease, in which case the T stage is determined by the total tumor size.
Tumor size is determined by gross or microscopic measurement.
Tumor size should not include any associated ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).
Vascular invasion status does not affect T stage.
The number of positive lymph nodes does not affect T stage.
